de.esoco.lib.expression.monad

Class Option<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.expression.monad.Option<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Functor<T>, Monad<T,Option<?>>

    public class Option<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Monad<T,Option<?>>
    A Monad implementation for optional values.

      • of

        public static <T> Option<T> of(T rValue)

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        The new instance

      • ofAll

        public static <T> Option<java.util.Collection<T>> ofAll(java.util.Collection<Option<T>> rOptions)
        Converts a collection of options into either an existing option of a collection of values if all options in the collection exist or into none() if one or more options in the collection do not exist.

        Other than ofExisting(Stream) this transformation cannot be performed on a stream (of possibly indefinite size) because existence needs to be determined upon invocation.

        Parameters:
        rOptions - The collection of options to convert
        Returns:
        A new option of a collection of the values of all options or none() if one or more options do not exist

      • ofExisting

        public static <T> Option<java.util.stream.Stream<T>> ofExisting(java.util.stream.Stream<Option<T>> rOptions)
        Converts a stream of options into an option of a stream of existing values.
        Parameters:
        rOptions - The stream to convert
        Returns:
        A new option containing a stream of existing values

      • and

        public <V,R,N extends Monad<V,Option<?>>> Option<R> and(N rOther,
                                                        java.util.function.BiFunction<? super T,? super V,? extends R> fJoin)
        Combines this monad with another monad into a new monad of the same type. This is done by invoking Monad.flatMap(Function) on this instance and "lifting" the other monad by invoking it's Monad.map(Function) method. Therefore this type of method is sometimes also called "lift" or "liftM2".

        Implementations should override this method to return their own type but they can simply invoke the default implementation ( Monad.super.and(rOther, fJoin)) and cast the result to their own type. The explicit declaration in subclasses is necessary because of the limitations of Java's generic type system.

        Specified by:
        and in interface Monad<T,Option<?>>
        Parameters:
        rOther - The other monad to combine with
        fJoin - A binary function that joins the values of both monads
        Returns:
        The new joined monad

      • exists

        public final boolean exists()
        Test whether this option represents an existing value.
        Returns:
        TRUE if this option exists, FALSE if it is undefined (none())

      • filter

        public Option<T> filter(java.util.function.Predicate<T> pCriteria)
        Filter this option according to the given criteria by returning an option that exists depending on whether the value fulfills the criteria.
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • flatMap

        public <R,N extends Monad<R,Option<?>>> Option<R> flatMap(java.util.function.Function<? super T,N> fMap)
        Converts this option into another option by applying a mapping function that produces an option with the target type from the value of this instance.

        Other than Java's Optional this implementation respects the monad laws of left and right identity as well as associativity. It does so by considering the not existing value none() as equivalent to NULL. Therefore, if the mapping function is invoked on a non-existing option it will receive NULL as it's argument and should be able to handle it.

        If the mapping function throws a NullPointerException it will be caught and the returned option will be none(). This allows to use functions that are not NULL-aware as an argument. It has the limitation that NPEs caused by nested code will not be thrown.

        Specified by:
        flatMap in interface Monad<T,Option<?>>
        Parameters:
        fMap - The mapping function
        Returns:
        The resulting option

      • is

        public final boolean is(java.lang.Class<?> rDatatype)
        A convenience method for a fast test of options for existence and a certain value datatype. This is especially helpful for options that are declared with a generic or common type (like Option<?> or Option<Object>).
        Parameters:
        rDatatype - The datatype to test the wrapped value against
        Returns:
        TRUE if this option exists and the value can be assigned to the given datatype

      • map

        public <R> Option<R> map(java.util.function.Function<? super T,? extends R> fMap)
        Maps this option to another one containing the result of invoking a mapping function on this instance's value. Other than Java's Optional this implementation respects the monad laws. See the description of flatMap(Function) for details.
        Specified by:
        map in interface Functor<T>
        Specified by:

        Parameters:
        fMap - The mapping function
        Returns:
        The mapped option
        See Also:
        Functor.map(Function)

      • orElse

        public Option<T> orElse(java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Exception> fHandler)
        Sets an operation that is performed if the functor doesn't contain a valid value. This can be used to define the alternative of a call to a monadic function like Functor.map(Function) and especially Functor.then(Consumer) to handle a failure case.

        Returns the resulting functor instance to allow chaining of further calls or assigning to a variable.

        Specified by:
        orElse in interface Functor<T>
        Parameters:
        fHandler - The consumer of the the error that occurred
        Returns:
        The resulting functor for chained invocations

      • orElse

        public void orElse(java.lang.Runnable fCode)
        A variant of orElse(Consumer) that simply executes some code if this option doesn't exist.
        Parameters:
        fCode - The code to execute

      • orFail

        public T orFail()
        Throws a NullPointerException if this option does not exist.
        Specified by:
        orFail in interface Functor<T>
        Returns:
        The functor's value
        See Also:
        Functor.orFail()

      • orGet

        public T orGet(java.util.function.Supplier<T> fSupply)
        A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or returns the result of invoking the given supplier if a valid value couldn't be determined.

        In general, calls to the monadic functions Functor.map(Function) or Functor.then(Consumer) should be preferred to processing values with consuming operations.

        Specified by:
        orGet in interface Functor<T>
        Parameters:
        fSupply - The supplier to invoke if no regular value could be determined
        Returns:
        The resulting value

      • orThrow

        public <E extends java.lang.Exception> T orThrow(java.util.function.Function<java.lang.Exception,E> fMapException)
                                          throws E extends java.lang.Exception
        A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or throws a mapped exception if a valid value couldn't be determined.

        In general, calls to the monadic functions Functor.map(Function) or Functor.then(Consumer) should be preferred to processing values with consuming operations.

        Specified by:
        orThrow in interface Functor<T>
        Parameters:
        fMapException - A function that maps the original exception
        Returns:
        The result of the execution
        Throws:
        E - The argument exception in the case of a failure
        E extends java.lang.Exception

      • orUse

        public T orUse(T rDefault)
        A consuming operation that either returns the functor's value or returns the given default value if a valid value couldn't be determined. The default implementation wraps the argument value into a Supplier and invokes Functor.orGet(Supplier).

        In general, calls to the monadic functions Functor.map(Function) or Functor.then(Consumer) should be preferred to processing values with consuming operations.

        Specified by:
        orUse in interface Functor<T>
        Parameters:
        rDefault - The value to return if no regular value could be determined
        Returns:
        The resulting value

      • then

        public Option<T> then(java.util.function.Consumer<? super T> fConsumer)
        Redefined here to provide a default implementation and to change the return type to Monad. Subclasses can typically just invoke super and declare their own type as the return type.
        Specified by:
        then in interface Functor<T>
        Specified by:

        Parameters:

        Returns:
